title.narrative: WATER:WASH

description.narrative: By 2020, government has increased capacity to lead and coordinate Humanitarian Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH) partnerships to meet the needs of the impacted populations, which contributes to Cross-Sectoral - Monitoring, Data And Situation Analyses, Safe And Equitable Water, Sanitation And Hygiene Services And Practices, Wash In Schools And Ecd Centres, Wash â€“ General, Water Supply, Water, Sanitation And Hygiene Systems And Empowerment Of Communities. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2020, people in targeted rural, small towns, and peri-urban areas use sustainable and safe drinking water services, adequate sanitation and improved hygiene practices.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2020, government has increased capacity to lead and coordinate Humanitarian WASH partnerships to meet the needs of the impactedpopulations

description.narrative: Nearly 123,000 people got access to at least basic water supply, and over 56,000 on a limited basis through a mix of development and recovery interventions, plus durable solutions via emergency funds that included 364 boreholes, six solar water supply systems, and a revolving fund for water supply for household connections in small towns.; Additionally, over 2 million people were assisted through Covid-19 sustainability of services support.At institutional level, 103 schools and 33 health centres gained access to safe water supply services, ensuring safe and reliable sources of water for schoolchildren and health service users. | Status:Met | As-of Date:11/01/2022
